questions.text: Which among the following is a subcutaneous fungal agent?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sporothrix schenckii Sporothrix schenckii is a subcutaneous fungal agent. The other three mentioned are systemic mycoses. Sporothrix schenckii can infect humans and is the causative agent of Sporotrichosis, commonly known as "rose handler's disease." The most common route of infection is the introduction of spores to the body through a cut or puncture wound in the skin. Infection commonly occurs in otherwise healthy individuals but is rarely life-threatening and can be treated with antifungals. FIG: Nodules along the line of lymphatic drainage.

questions.text: Choose the wrong statement about Plasmodium species:

options.label: A
options.text: Drug resistant falciparum is seen in India

options.label: B
options.text: Presence of Duffy blood group antigen is protective for P. vivax

options.label: C
options.text: Cerebral malaria with shock by P. falciparum is called algid malaria

options.label: D
options.text: Relapse is seen in P. ovale

questions.correct_answer: B. Presence of Duffy blood group antigen is protective for P. vivax
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Presence of Duffy blood group antigen is protective for P. vivax The absence, not the presence, of the Duffy group antigen, is protective against P. vivax Because the Duffy antigen normally serves as the receptor for Plasmodium vivax. Therefore Duffy – negative phenotypes are resistant to P. Vivax invasion and is most commonly seen in black individuals of Africa.

questions.text: Mw vaccine is extracted from which bacteria, mentioned below:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

M. Indicus pranii Mycobacterium w vaccine is extracted from M. Indicus pranii (heat killed suspension of nonpathogenic, cultivable, atypical bacteria) MIP immunotherapy is used as an adjunct to chemotherapy for category 2 tuberculosis and adjunct to multidrug therapy multi bacillary regimen in leprosy patients with high bacillary index.

Highyeild:

Leprosy, a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae, is endemic in many regions of the world. Due to the difficulty in cultivating M. leprae in artificial media, vaccine strategies have centered on the use of cross-sensitizing mycobacteria. Bacillus Calmette–Guerin (BCG) has been the most popular among these, but with a widely varying protective efficacy reported from different parts of the world. In three meta-analyses, BCG has shown strong evidence of efficacy against leprosy. Recently, India has focused interest on another vaccine, Mycobacterium indicus pranii vaccine earlier known as Mycobacterium w. To overcome the limitations of these whole cell vaccines, various recombinant BCGs and subunit vaccines have been developed and studied in experimental models. These often yield inconsistent results. However, a new subunit recombinant vaccine – LepVax holds promise and has completed Phase 1a clinical trials successfully.

questions.text: The following vector is not involved in transmission of this disease:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Kyasanur forest disease Kyasanur forest disease (KFD) is a tick-borne viral hemorrhagic fever endemic to South India . The disease is caused by a virus belonging to the family Flaviviridae , which also includes yellow fever and dengue fever , which are transmitted by monkeys.

Highyeild:

The vector for disease transmission is Haemaphysalis spinigera . The vector given in the above picture is a sandfly ( Haemaphysalis spinigera ) and it transmits Kala-azar Oriental sore Chandipura virus Sandfly fever Oroya Fever

questions.text: A 22 year old college going adult has H/o sexual exposure with commercial sex worker, now presenting with painful genital lesions and lymphadenopathy in right inguinal region. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Chancroid Chancroid is a bacterial sexually transmitted disease (STD) caused by infection with Haemophilus ducreyi. It is characterized by painful necrotizing genital ulcers that may be accompanied by inguinal lymphadenopathy (painful – usually unilateral lymph nodes) Chancroid is caused by the bacterium Haemophilus ducreyi and results in painful, superficial ulcers, often with regional lymphadenopathy. Chancroid occurs in Asia, Africa, and the Caribbean, and is an important cofactor of HIV transmission. The genital ulcer from chancroid is painful, tender, and nonindurated.

Table:

#MANTRA GENITAL ULCERS DISEASE CAUSATIVE AGENT CLINICAL FEATURES CHANCROID Haemophilus ducreyi Multiple, painful genital ulcers with tender lymphadenopathy DONOVANOSIS (GRANULOMA INGUINALE) Klebsiella granulomatis Painless genital ulcers without lymphadenopathy LGV Chlamydia trachomatis (L1,L2,L3) Painless , shallow genital ulcers with painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (painful buboes)

questions.text: Which among the following occupation is a risk factor for this presenting illness?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A kennel worker The above image shows cutaneous larva migrans. Being a kennel worker is a risk factor for this job as exposure to animal feces is high. Cutaneous larva migrans is a parasitic skin infection caused by hookworm larvae that usually infest cats, dogs and other animals. Humans can be infected with the larvae by walking barefoot on sandy beaches or contacting moist soft soil that has been contaminated with animal faeces

questions.text: Transmission assessment survey is carried out for:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Filariasis Transmission assessment survey is carried out for filariasis as filariasis elimination needs mass drug administration . The transmission assessment survey (TAS) is used to determine when infections have been reduced below target thresholds and Mass Drug Administration can stop. Once MDA has stopped, TAS is used as a surveillance tool to determine that infection levels are sustained below target thresholds.

Highyeild:

Transmission assessment Survey (TAS) A TAS is the basis for a decision to move from MDA to post-MDA surveillance Technical aspect Guidance Geographical area Evaluation Unit (EU) When survey should be conducted When all the eligibility criteria are met At least 6 months after the last round of MDA Target population Children aged 6-7 years Diagnostic tests W. bancrofti areas: ICT Brugia spp. areas: Brugia Rapid ™ Survey design Cluster sampling or systematic sampling in schools or the community, or a census A TAS is a simplified version of the 'stopping-MDA survey' protocol.

questions.text: Which immunoglobulin is elevated in a case of chronic allergy?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

IgE IgE levels are elevated in chronic allergy. IgE antibodies are normally found in small amounts in the blood, but higher amounts can be a sign that the body overreacts to allergens. This can lead to an allergic reaction. IgE levels can also be high when the body is fighting off an infection from a parasite or with some immune system conditions. Allergy (Type I hypersensitivity) is always IgE mediated both in acute and chronic phases.

questions.text: A patient got exposed to Hepatitis B infection. Which of the following markers will always be present in the patient even if he becomes chronic or recurrent?
A 40 years old male from Himachal Pradesh has presented with verrucous lesions in the skin with following microscopic findings from the tissue biopsy. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Chromoblastomycosis The given clinical history and histopathological image are suggestive of chromoblastomycosis. Chromoblastomycosis is a chronic fungal infection of the skin and the subcutaneous tissue caused by traumatic inoculation of a specific group of dematiaceous fungi (usually Fonsecaea pedrosoi, Phialophora verrucosa, Cladosporium carrionii, or Fonsecaea compacta) through the skin. KOH mount or tissue biopsy and staining of the lesion shows – Irregular, dark brown bodies with septae (yeast like bodies) called Sclerotic bodies.

questions.text: A HIV patient with fever, chronic diarrhea presented to OPD. His stool was examined which showed the following oocysts. Identify the components used for staining the stool?

options.label: A
options.text: Diluted Carbol Fuchsin, 20% H2S04 and Methylene blue

options.label: B
options.text: Strong Carbol Fuchsin, 0.5% H2S04 and Loeffler's methylene blue

options.label: C
options.text: Strong Carbol Fuchsin, 1% H2S04, iodine and methylene blue

options.label: D
options.text: Diluted carbol Fuchsin, 5% H2S04 and methylene blue

questions.correct_answer: B. Strong Carbol Fuchsin, 0.5% H2S04 and Loeffler's methylene blue
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Strong Carbol Fuchsin, 0.5% H2S04 and Loeffler's methylene blue Diarrhea in an HIV patient is suggestive of a coccidian parasitic infestation. The image shows a blue background and red/pink stains suggest acid-fast stain positive Cryptosporidium parvum. ZN STAINING / ACID FAST STAINING This method is mainly to visualize the acid fast organisms. Organism is seen in pink colour with a blue background.

questions.text: A 48 year old man, hospitalized for 17 days and on IV antibiotics followed by oral course of drugs for acute febrile illness with neutropenia. He had a history of dysuria while admitted and now complaints of loose stools and abdominal pain. Which antibiotic usage has the highest risk for developing pseudomembranous colitis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Amino penicillin Pseudomembranous colitis, also called antibiotic-associated colitis or C. difficile colitis, is inflammation of the colon associated with an overgrowth of the bacterium Clostridium difficile. While almost any antibiotic can cause pseudomembranous colitis, some antibiotics are more commonly linked to pseudomembranous colitis than others, including: 3rd generation’s cephalosporins like Ceftriaxone followed by aminopenicillins, Fluoroquinolones, such as ciprofloxacin and levofloxacin.

#MANTRA
